metadata.sermon_start_end: The secret of the Lorp is with them that fear him; and he will shew them his covenant. Mine eyes are ever toward the Lor; for he shall pluck my feet out of the net. (Psalm 25:14-15) Our Father and our God, we hold before thee the [...] Faith is a living adventure with God.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to focus on a specific passage. It begins with Psalm 25, but quickly shifts to a general discourse on fear, eventually using the narrative of the storm on the Sea of Galilee as an illustrative example rather than an object of exposition. It treats the Bible as a source of 'ideas' or 'insights' rather than a specific proclamatory word.
quotes: When the wise old book speaks of the fear of the Lord as the beginning of wisdom, it says a great deal...
In the account of the storm on the Sea of Galilee... we see a perfect example of men dealing wisely with the awful instinct of fear.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one pericope and identify what is unique to that specific text that cannot be found elsewhere. Avoid jumping between the Psalms and the Gospels to support a pre-conceived theme.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no evidence of linguistic or historical-critical exegesis. The preacher treats the texts as timeless psychological allegories. The 'secret of the Lord' in Psalm 25 is ignored in favor of a modern psychological definition of fear. The original context of Israel or the early church is entirely absent.
quotes: Primitive man's life was surrounded by terrors.
The Master, so the account runs in the Gospel, is tired and weary from the pulls and demands made on him...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Engage with the Hebrew/Greek text and the specific theological context of the biblical author. Explain what 'Covenant' (Psalm 25) meant to the original audience before applying it.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: While the sermon mentions contemporary anxieties (atomic death, Hitler), the application remains largely general and psychological. It offers 'faith' as a general solution to 'fear' without concrete ecclesial or ethical direction. It borders on a lecture on human psychology rather than a sermon.
quotes: An assistant city prosecutor in St. Louis said suddenly... 'I am afraid of atomic death.'
A person cannot be an adult believing Christian and hold his faith in magic...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond general psychological states to concrete obedience in the context of the modern zeitgeist, avoiding 'general truths' which Dekker forbids.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is more of a thematic essay than an interwoven exposition. Because there is no rigorous exposition, the application is not 'drawn out' of the text but rather 'read into' it. The text serves as a springboard for the preacher's own thoughts on courage and faith.
quotes: Now, that is the position many of us try to take. We attempt to run from our fears...
Incidentally, we might all learn from Jesus in this regard.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Allow the text to 'expound' the hearer. The movement should be from the specific Word to the hearer's life, not from a human problem to a biblical illustration.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The category of 'misery' is present but interpreted psychologically as 'fear' and 'despair' rather than theological misery (sin/estrangement before God). Redemption is presented as 'faith' and 'victory' through Christ, but it leans toward human subjectivity rather than an objective act of God.
quotes: We confess that we have not loved and trusted thee as we ought.
Victory is the supreme shout of the light centered in Christ.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the understanding of misery beyond 'instinct' to man's condition before God. Ensure redemption is seen as God's work, not just a psychological shift in the hearer.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are largely absent. While 'despair' is mentioned, the ultimate seriousness of being lost (temporal or eternal) is softened by a general optimism about God's care. There is no sharp call to decision or warning of destruction.
quotes: No child stubs his toe but that the Father knoweth and careth.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Incorporate the gravity of human choice and the possibility of being lost, as Dekker emphasizes that traditions ignoring this fail to take God seriously.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as the one who calms the storm and the source of victory. However, he often appears as an example ('we might all learn from Jesus') rather than the ontological Lord and telos. The doctrine of the two natures is not explicitly utilized to ground the grace offered.
quotes: Victory is the supreme shout of the light centered in Christ.
The Master chose to retreat for rest and renewal and to alternate between work and rest.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Present Christ not as a moral example for dealing with fear, but as the God-man who is the objective end (telos) of the life of the hearer.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1350 words, the sermon would take about 13-14 minutes to deliver. According to Dekker's Thesis 8, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for 'depth'.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exposition and the concrete application to meet the minimum 20-minute threshold for substantive preaching.

overall_assessment.summary: The text functions more as a religious-psychological address than a sermon according to Dekker's criteria. It lacks a rigorous focus on a single Bible passage, substitutes exegesis with psychological observations, and fails to reach the required length for depth. While it addresses 'misery' in the form of fear, it lacks the sharp edge of the 'two ways' and the specificity of the Word.
strengths: Thematic consistency regarding the human condition of fear.
Clear attempt to point toward Christ as the source of victory.
Avoidance of 'magic' and 'superstition' in favor of a more robust faith.
weaknesses: Lack of specific biblical exposition; the text is used illustratively.
Insufficient length (13-14 minutes) to achieve theological depth.
Psychological categories dominate over dogmatic and exegetical ones.
Absence of the 'two ways' and the seriousness of being lost.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the sense of Dekker's definition. It is a thematic speech about a biblical idea (fear/faith) rather than an exposition and application of a specific Bible passage. It lacks the formal rigor and the substantive '3-2-1' depth required for true proclamation.
